Authors:
Diana Wrigley de Basanta, Arturo Estrada-Torres, Ivan
Garcia-Cunchillos, Asuncion Cano Echevarria, Carlos Lado
Title:
Didymium azorellae, a new myxomycete from cushion plants of
cold arid areas of South America
Keywords:
Amoebozoa, Azorella, Neotropics, SEM, taxonomy,
xerophiles
Abstract:
A new species of Didymium (Myxomycetes), D. azorellae is
described, isolated from plant debris in moist chamber, collected during
studies of cold arid areas of Argentina and Peru. It can be
distinguished by its small size, the tightly packed layer of lime
crystals on the peridium, the very scant, or absent, capillitium, and
the unique spore ornamentation, especially by SEM. The species developed
on dead leaves of cushion plants growing in the extremely harsh
environments of the central Andean puna at almost 5000 m elevation, and
the Andino-Patagonian steppe. Morphology was examined using scanning
electron microscopy and light microscopy, and micrographs of relevant
details are included here. In order to confirm the phylogenetic position
of the new species described in this paper, a molecular study was
conducted based on two independent nuclear regions. Two sequences from
different specimens and two different countries of the newly described
species D. azorellae were grouped together and separated from the rest
of the species analyzed. The clades are well supported for both.
